## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsView.ModeChanging> event is raised when a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsView> control attempts to change between edit, insert, and read-only mode, but before the mode actually changes. This allows you to provide an event handler that performs a custom routine, such as configuring the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsView> control for a specific mode or canceling the mode change, whenever this event occurs.
A DetailsViewModeEventArgs object is passed to the event handler, which allows you to determine the mode to which the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsView> control is changing, to determine whether the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsView.ModeChanging> event was raised as a result of the user canceling an edit operation, or to indicate that an insert operation should be canceled. To determine the new mode, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsViewModeEventArgs.NewMode%2A> property. You can also use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsViewModeEventArgs.NewMode%2A> property to change to an alternate mode by setting it to one of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsViewMode> enumeration values. Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsViewModeEventArgs.CancelingEdit%2A> property to determine whether the user canceled an edit operation. To cancel an insert operation, set the <xref:System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs.Cancel%2A> property to `true`.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
For a list of initial property values for an instance of the DetailsViewModeEventArgs class, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DetailsViewModeEventArgs.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
